blocks.text:
The actual spherical excess is

$E = \left( \frac{73^{\circ}47'35'' + 67^{\circ}56'57'' + 51^{\circ}15'28''}{180^{\circ}} \right)$.

There is thus $E$ to be divided among the angles, according to the respective weights; and these weights are in the proportion

$\frac{1}{250}, \frac{1}{200}, \frac{1}{150}$.

The sum of the weights being $250$. 

Hence the corrections to the angles are: $\rho = 219^{\circ}12'18'', \sigma = 250^{\circ} + 26 = 250^{\circ} 26'18'', \tau = 39^{\circ}17'47''$ and, as these corrections bring about the spherical excess greater than we should take the next highest value. 

These corrections are $875, 555, and 890$. This consequently gives the true angles as $E = 75^{\circ}12'47'', \sigma = 75^{\circ}20'47'', \tau = 75^{\circ}20'47''$.

Example 1: A set of observations by a land surveyor were made by the last rest. Compare the two results from the point of accuracy, and find the most probable value of the angle.

The area of the set A is $76^{\circ}40'31''$ and A.M. of set B is $76^{\circ}51'58''$.
